conclusion: To determine the heat exchange Q in the cyclic process A → B → C → D → A, we need to analyze each segment of the cycle and apply the first law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
ΔU is the change in internal energy, Q is the heat added to the system, and W is the work done by the system.
A to B is an isothermal expansion (constant temperature).
B to C is an isobaric compression (constant pressure).
C to D is an isothermal compression (constant temperature).
D to A is an isobaric expansion (constant pressure).

premise: A to B is an isothermal expansion.
conclusion: Work done by the gas during isothermal expansion: W_AB = nRT ln(V_B/V_A).

premise: B to C is an isobaric compression.
conclusion: Work done on the gas during isobaric compression: W_BC = P (V_B - V_C).

premise: C to D is an isothermal compression.
conclusion: Work done on the gas during isothermal compression: W_CD = nRT ln(V_C/V_D).

premise: D to A is an isobaric expansion.
conclusion: Work done by the gas during isobaric expansion: W_DA = P (V_D - V_A).

premise: The net work done in a cyclic process is the area enclosed by the cycle on the P-V diagram.
conclusion: The area under A → B and C → D (isothermal processes) cancel each other out.

premise: The net work is the area of the rectangle formed by B → C and D → A.
For a cyclic process, the change in internal energy over a complete cycle is zero.
Using the first law of thermodynamics for the entire cycle: ΔU_cycle = Q_cycle - W_net.
